required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Trial Comparing Relapse Rates Between Standard Ureteroscopic Removal Of Ureteral Stone And Standard Removal With Additional Ureterorenic Clearing Of Non-Symptomatic Stones In The Kidney
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Trial Comparing Relapse Rates Between Standard Ureteroscopic Removal Of Ureteral Stone And Standard Removal With Additional Ureterorenic Clearing Of Non-Symptomatic Stones In The Kidney

collaborator.agency: University of Washington Medical Center Department of Urology (Seattle, WA)
Veterans Administration Puget Sound Heath Care System (Seattle, WA).

brief_summary.textblock: Patients with a ureteral (the tube that leads from the kidney to the bladder) stone often also have small stones in the kidney (frequently visible on CT). If these small kidney stones are determined to be asymptomatic (not causing any problems or pain), then most urologists will simply remove the symptomatic ureteral stone and leave the additional stones in the kidney above. However, the investigators know that the ureteral stone started in the kidney. This means that the small stones remaining in the patient's kidney may cause problems later. The purpose of our research is to test if removing small stones from the kidney prevents future stone episodes

primary_outcome.measure: Relapse of stone disease on the treated side
primary_outcome.time_frame: annually up to 5 years after stone removal surgery
primary_outcome.description: Radiological evidence of significant growth in the size of any pre-existing stone Radiological identification of a new stone that was not visible in the previous scan Passage of a stone with pain symptoms on the treated side

arm_group.description: Group 1 will receive the standard treatment of having only the ureteral stone removed

arm_group.arm_group_label: Asymptomatic kidney stones and ureteral stone removed
arm_group.description: Group 2 will include the step of having the asymptomatic kidney stones removed in addition to the ureteral stone

intervention.description: Ureteral stone removal by the surgical procedure called Ureteroscopy

intervention.intervention_name: Asymptomatic kidney stones and ureteral stone removed
intervention.description: Asymptomatic kidney stones and Ureteral stone removal by the surgical procedure called Ureteroscopy
intervention.arm_group_label: Asymptomatic kidney stones and ureteral stone removed

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients scheduled to undergo ureteroscopic removal of ureteral stone(s) that are visible on KUB (x-ray) or CT (i.e., calcium stones)
- Current CT scan within the 90-day pre-operative period
- Recurrent (having had previous stones) or multiple stones (simultaneous bilateral stones)
- Able to give informed consent
- Age 21 years or older
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to give informed consent
- Age less than 21 years
- Stones not visible on KUB or CT
- Patients with systemic disease or renal anatomical disorders (RTA, primary hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, enteric hyperoxaluria, medullary sponge kidney)

facility.name: University of Washington Medical Center Department of Urology
Veterans Administration Puget Sound Heath Care System
